reasoning: [Specific Program Not Verified] Paper mentions 'E-commerce demonstration county pilots' but search could not confirm this as graduation program: Perplexity search result: The 'E-commerce demonstration county pilots' in China, most commonly known as the National Rural E-commerce Comprehensive Demonstration Project (NRECDP), is a government-led initiative aimed at reducing poverty and promoting income growth in rural areas through the expansion of e-commerce infrastructure, road and internet access, and skills training[1][4][7]. It primarily provides market access, logistics infrastructure, digital skills, and entrepreneurship development, but there is no robust evidence that it directly provides unconditional cash transfers or productive physical assets to poor households as core program components. Instead, it focuses on enabling environments for rural e-commerce, such as training, ICT platforms, and logistics, to facilitate income growth via market opportunities[1][2][4]. Some local variations may offer microcredit or training, but the core intervention is not asset transfer or cash stipend. Graduation programs, as defined in the literature (e.g., BRAC's model), usually involve multi-component interventions for ultra-poor households including both asset transfers and cash support, which is not the design here. The available evidence from multiple impact evaluations, World Bank reports, and academic studies indicates positive income effects, but primarily through enabling entrepreneurship rather than direct resource transfer. | Graduation: NO, Cash: NO, Assets: NO | Confidence: HIGH | Sources: https://centaur.reading.ac.uk/115883/1/Zhang,%20Millan,%20Money%20&%20Guo_E-commerce%20Development,%20Poverty%20Reduction%20and%20Income%20Growth%20in%20Rural%20China.pdf, https://www.cgdev.org/sites/default/files/e-commerce-and-mobile-money-poverty-reduction-china-lessons-african-countries.pdf, https://documents1.worldbank.org/curated/en/552791574361533437/pdf/E-commerce-Development-Experience-from-China.pdf
